verses.text: This is the third time I am coming to you. Every matter must be established by the testimony of two or three witnesses.
verses.comment: Paul refers to a principle from Deuteronomy, emphasizing the importance of witness and accountability in the church community. The cross-reference to Matthew shows this principle continued in the teachings of Jesus.

verses.text: I warned those who sinned before, and all the others, and I warn them now, as I did when I was present the second time. If I come again, I will not spare anyone—
verses.comment: Paul expresses his apostolic authority and the seriousness of discipline within the church. The repetition shows his pastoral concern for correction and unity.

verses.text: since you seek proof that Christ is speaking through me. He is not weak toward you, but is powerful among you.
verses.comment: Paul affirms Christ’s power is present in the apostolic ministry, linking the authority of church leaders to Christ’s own authority. The reference to Matthew supports Christ’s universal authority after His resurrection.

verses.text: For indeed, He was crucified in weakness, yet He lives by the power of God. We also are weak in Him, but we will live with Him by God’s power toward you.
verses.comment: Paul outlines the paradox of Christ’s humility and divine power—a foundation for Christian life and resurrection. Spiritual union with Christ brings life through God’s power.

verses.text: Examine yourselves to see whether you are in the faith. Test yourselves. Do you not recognize that Jesus Christ is in you—unless indeed you fail the test?
verses.comment: Self-examination is stressed here for spiritual authenticity. The indwelling of Christ is a touchstone for genuine faith; parallels to John’s teaching on Christ’s presence are strong.

verses.text: And I hope you will realize that we have not failed the test.
verses.comment: Paul desires assurance from the Corinthians of his authentic apostleship and their recognition of the truth he brings as a divinely appointed servant.

verses.text: Now we pray to God that you may not do anything wrong—not that we may appear approved, but that you may do what is right, even if we seem to have failed.
verses.comment: The focus is on the moral and spiritual growth of the Corinthians, prioritizing holiness and integrity even above personal reputation of church leaders.

verses.text: For we cannot do anything against the truth, but only for the truth.
verses.comment: Commitment to truth is emphasized, echoing Christ’s testimony before Pilate. The spiritual role of leaders is always under truth’s authority.

verses.text: For we rejoice when we are weak but you are strong. Our prayer is for your restoration.
verses.comment: The apostolic longing for the spiritual maturity and full restoration of the church community is evident here, connecting with broader scriptural calls for completeness and unity among believers.

verses.text: This is why I write these things while I am away, so that when I come I may not have to be severe in my use of the authority the Lord has given me for building up and not for tearing down.
verses.comment: Here Paul reminds that church authority’s goal is to edify and encourage—not merely to correct. This points to the legitimate and constructive function of spiritual leadership.

verses.text: Finally, brothers, rejoice. Put things in order, encourage one another, be of one mind, live in peace; and the God of love and peace will be with you.
verses.comment: Unity and order in the church are commanded, with an assurance of God’s presence. The importance of spiritual peace and harmony links the church’s witness to God’s nature.

verses.text: Greet one another with a holy kiss.
verses.comment: This practice demonstrates early Christian fellowship and expresses unity and sacred affection among believers, a significant sign of spiritual communion.
Paul highlights the broader spiritual family and the concept of the communion of saints, reinforcing the unity that transcends local congregations.

verses.text: The grace of the Lord Jesus Christ, the love of God, and the fellowship of the Holy Spirit be with you all.
verses.comment: This benediction is an early reference to the triune nature of God—Father, Son, and Holy Spirit—underscoring the spiritual unity and divine life shared within the Church. The links reveal Christ’s promise of the Spirit and the diversity of spiritual gifts in the one body.
